bullets.text: U.S. PPI rose 0.2% in November; goods +0.9% while services were flat, suggesting goods-led pipeline inflation pressure.
Fed Beige Book: businesses increasingly pass tariff-related costs to consumers, raising near-term inflation risks and complicating disinflation.
U.S. retail sales strengthened in November while wholesale inflation was softer than expected, signaling resilient demand with easing price pressures.
Existing home sales beat expectations to end 2025; prices eased further, pointing to improving transaction volumes despite still-high borrowing costs.
Bank of America and Citigroup topped earnings estimates on stronger net interest income and trading, indicating large-bank profitability remains solid.
U.S.-Iran tensions: personnel moved from Qatar base; Gulf allies oppose strikes; oil fell on hints of delay—risk premium remains headline-driven.
U.S. seeks expanded Venezuelan oil dealings, reshaping ties; Senate vote blocked a Venezuela war-powers check, preserving executive flexibility.
Trump administration cleared Nvidia H200 chip sales to China with a 25% surcharge, signaling a more transactional approach to AI export controls.
OpenAI reportedly signed a ~$10B compute deal with Cerebras, underscoring escalating AI infrastructure spending and competition for specialized chips.
xAI disabled Grok’s sexualized real-person image generation amid backlash; California DOJ probe highlights rising regulatory and liability risk for generative AI.
Climate indicators worsened: 2025 ocean heat uptake was exceptionally high and the last three years were record-hot, strengthening urgency around Arctic/Greenland geopolitics.
BEA’s Q3 2025 international transactions data spotlight the current-account balance and cross-border capital flows, key to dollar funding conditions.
